htmlEmbed:
Republicans raise money on Facebook by tying migrant influx to covid surgeIsaac Stanley-Becker8/10/2021

Sen. John Barrasso is among those seeking donations by suggesting immigrants are exacerbating the pandemic. Last year Facebook said a similar claim amounted to hate speech.

PoliticsRead

class="teaser-content"><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="7KVBJYAMBZB2BFTBYSSXY76IJA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Facebook has allowed prominent Republican officials and candidates  including the chairman of the Senate Republican Conference  to use the platforms powerful ad technologies to raise money by associating migrants with the surge of <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/?itid=lk_inline_manual_2" target="_blank" class="contextual_link">coronavirus</a> infections in the southern United States.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="DAACAEXHZJB37B5GMTCJHC4BWI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The ads, whose central claim has been <a href="https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-health-immigration-coronavirus-pandemic-174e424da1eb061d8b8bd53a7192611b" target=_blank>rejected by doctors</a> and <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2021/08/06/fact-check-covid-19-variants-not-migrants-u-s-mexico-border/5420387001/" target=_blank>fact-checkers</a>, illustrate the platforms inconsistent approach to defining<b> </b>coronavirus misinformation, especially when elected officials are involved. Facebooks management of misleading content is under intense scrutiny by the Biden administration as coronavirus case numbers <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/08/10/coronavirus-covid-live-updates-us/?itid=lk_inline_manual_4" target=_blank>climb again in the United States</a> and health authorities grapple with the role of social media in shaping anti-vaccine attitudes. Biden raised alarm about the issue last month when he <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-vaccine-social-media/2021/07/16/fbc434bc-e666-11eb-8aa5-5662858b696e_story.html?itid=lk_inline_manual_4" target=_blank>said in relation to Facebook</a>, Theyre killing people.</p></div></div><div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="MY32MMS7MRCSJLWZLYMZPVFJ6U" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The latest test of the social media giants policies joins the inflamed debate over immigration to the life-or-death matter of the novel coronavirus.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="PJLV wpds-c-jAbMAP PJLV-ijpwmQx-css hide-for-print mb-md class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="ER6XVBDQUZCKLGJ7JDWVZACXUU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The CDC & Joe Biden are telling Americans to MASK UP but are letting THOUSANDS of COVID-19 positive illegal immigrants into our country! warns an ad from Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Republican Conference and a physician.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="DB3CNP2ERRCU5MEKBWJTLEWO4Q" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The ad, which began running on Aug. 6, has been viewed as many as 15,000 times, according to Facebooks ad archive. It directs users to a petition calling on Biden to visit the southern border  and, ultimately, to a fundraising page benefiting the senators campaign committee, Friends of John Barrasso.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="D5WUDOQWUREJ3PA7U2S3Z2I75U" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Similar ads  also asking for financial contributions and sponsored by multiple Republican members of Congress, candidates and super PACs  have blanketed the platform in recent days. Many represent congressional districts far from the southern border.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="PJLV wpds-c-jAbMAP PJLV-ijpwmQx-css hide-for-print mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg"><div class="wpds-c-cypqlZ"><div class="wpds-c-euUgLV wpds-c-euUgLV-itqkRF-isDark-true wpds-c-euUgLV-ilkUbus-css dib"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="wpds-c-lnfcBU wpds-c-lnfcBU-ibJutop-css"><div class="wpds-c-kJQDNY"><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-ilkktda-css">Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-mobile"><div aria-hidden="true" class="PJLV wpds-c-jAbMAP PJLV-igirQCV-css hide-for-print mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm ad-mobile"><div class="wpds-c-cypqlZ"><div class="wpds-c-euUgLV wpds-c-euUgLV-itqkRF-isDark-true wpds-c-euUgLV-idLEMlM-css dib"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="wpds-c-lnfcBU wpds-c-lnfcBU-ibJutop-css"><div class="wpds-c-kJQDNY"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="6XGD5UDBVRHVRPVXFRZTP7KSEE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">An ad from Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) asserts that thousands of unvaccinated illegal immigrants enjoy more leniency than American citizens when it comes to health protocols. An ad from Rep. Ted Budd (R-N.C.) warns bluntly, If Joe Biden really wanted to get COVID-19 under control in our country, he would address the crisis at our southern border. Letting unvaccinated ILLEGAL immigrants come into our country is a threat to American citizens. And an ad from Rep. August Pfluger (R-Tex.) alleges, Hundreds of thousands of migrants are pouring into Texas and thousands of them have tested positive for covid-19. All the ads link to fundraising pages.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="PG5PSFN7GVEF7HZ73K54PQ2LJQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Cramer said his ad does not target immigrants and is instead a criticism of Democratic leaders inconsistent liberal policies.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="D3KXOWBKUVGJLKZV5W7ZFFG4GE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Open borders for immigrants with no demands for proof of vaccinations while proposing mandates on American citizens is gross hypocrisy, he wrote in an email response to questions about his ad.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" dispute thousands of covid-positive illegal migrants have been released into the interior of Texas. Other lawmakers running such ads did not respond to requests for comment.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="CAFSZ5DWIFAM3EZOZNHG2ZIWGY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Facebooks allowing the ads appears to be in conflict with the technology giants move last fall to remove ads from President Donald Trumps reelection campaign asserting that accepting more refugees would exacerbate health risks related to the pandemic. At the time, Facebook representatives cited the companys policy against hate speech.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="JPZFOCVBUVEYJHQCU7JR6HEK2Q" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">We rejected these ads because we dont allow claims that peoples physical safety, health, or survival is threatened by people on the basis of their national origin or immigration status, a Facebook spokesman <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/09/30/biden-misinformation-earpiece-tiktok-facebook/?itid=lk_inline_manual_20" target=_blank>said in September 2020</a>.</p></div><div data-contentid="N7WQTPRMDVBN5MU7YGOXVRY4EE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Now, the claim has returned as Republicans seek to exact a political price from Biden for the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/biden-border-migrants-expulsion-flights/2021/08/06/1acd2762-f6f5-11eb-83e7-06a8a299c310_story.html?itid=lk_inline_manual_23" target=_blank>largest migrant influx</a> in at least two decades while also blaming him for the surge of coronavirus cases driven by the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/delta-variant-most-prevalent/2021/08/08/d1017f0e-f558-11eb-9068-bf463c8c74de_story.html?itid=lk_inline_manual_23" target=_blank>highly infectious delta variant</a>.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="LA7ZZLHKGZHUBK7AN5QE4KKSQQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Devon Kearns, a Facebook spokeswoman, said the ads run by the Republican officials do not violate the companys policies. She drew a distinction with Trumps claims last year by saying the new posts are attacking unvaccinated people or potentially people with covid, which isnt an attack on a protected group.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="DFBYNJTUARAOPI4RYI2VO7HVW4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The effort to tie the explosion of coronavirus cases to the arrival of migrants has gained currency among Republicans since it was articulated at a news conference and in a fundraising letter last week by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R). But the claim rings false to health experts and fact-checkers, who note that border authorities are denying entry to people more easily than is possible under ordinary immigration law because of an emergency order put in place by Trump in March 2020; that people crossing the border are screened more rigorously for the coronavirus than are members of the general population; and that the positivity rate among migrants in McAllen, Tex., which is at the center of the outcry, is lower than in the surrounding county.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="wpds-c-sFUaP wpds-c-sFUaP-iwFqEg-variant-interstitial wpds-c-sFUaP-iPJLV-css overrideStyles hide-for-print"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" data-testid="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/08/06/desantiss-effort-blame-biden-covid-surge-florida/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_26">Fact Checker: DeSantiss effort to blame Biden for the covid surge in Florida</a></span></p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="YOYPYEZQUJDL7OJOUQM5YDYKH4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Who knows if the politicians running these ads believe what theyre saying, said Imran Ahmed, founder and chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, a nonprofit organization that examines online extremism. But they know it pays to say they believe it. Theyve learned from all sorts of bad actors that you can monetize misinformation on social media.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="GKDKX74CQJGL5M2BQT6YDIUV4Q" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">To fulfill its promise to clean up its platform, Ahmed said, Facebook should become more proactive in vetting paid posts, rather than their default being to take every advertisement that someone wants to buy.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="FZYJEAX3UBGDHDKP2YKHXA7JZU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Its a commercial consideration, he added. There is a tension between their promise not to be a vector for disinformation and their desire to maximize profits.</p></div></div><div class="wpds-c-hQqFwa (Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post)","distributor":{"category":"staff"},"height":2333,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/3M43EAHUUEI6XJRWDDFMLGUY3Q.jpg","width":3500,"originalIdx":0},{"_id":"7KVBJYAMBZB2BFTBYSSXY76IJA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Facebook has allowed prominent Republican officials and candidates  including the chairman of the Senate Republican Conference  to use the platforms powerful ad technologies to raise money by associating migrants with the surge of \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"contextual_link\"\u003ecoronavirus\u003c/a\u003e infections in the southern United States.","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"DAACAEXHZJB37B5GMTCJHC4BWI","additional_properties":{},"content":"The ads, whose central claim has been \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-health-immigration-coronavirus-pandemic-174e424da1eb061d8b8bd53a7192611b\" target=_blank\u003erejected by doctors\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2021/08/06/fact-check-covid-19-variants-not-migrants-u-s-mexico-border/5420387001/\" target=_blank\u003efact-checkers\u003c/a\u003e, illustrate the platforms inconsistent approach to defining\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ecoronavirus misinformation, especially when elected officials are involved. Facebooks management of misleading content is under intense scrutiny by the Biden administration as coronavirus case numbers \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/08/10/coronavirus-covid-live-updates-us/\" target=_blank\u003eclimb again in the United States\u003c/a\u003e and health authorities grapple with the role of social media in shaping anti-vaccine attitudes. Biden raised alarm about the issue last month when he \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-vaccine-social-media/2021/07/16/fbc434bc-e666-11eb-8aa5-5662858b696e_story.html\" target=_blank\u003esaid in relation to Facebook\u003c/a\u003e, Theyre killing people.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"MY32MMS7MRCSJLWZLYMZPVFJ6U","additional_properties":{},"content":"The latest test of the social media giants policies joins the inflamed debate over immigration to the life-or-death matter of the novel coronavirus.","type":"text","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"ER6XVBDQUZCKLGJ7JDWVZACXUU","additional_properties":{},"content":"The CDC \u0026amp; Joe Biden are telling Americans to MASK UP but are letting THOUSANDS of COVID-19 positive illegal immigrants into our country! warns an ad from Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Republican Conference and a physician.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"DB3CNP2ERRCU5MEKBWJTLEWO4Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"The ad, which began running on Aug. 6, has been viewed as many as 15,000 times, according to Facebooks ad archive. It directs users to a petition calling on Biden to visit the southern border  and, ultimately, to a fundraising page benefiting the senators campaign committee, Friends of John Barrasso.","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"D5WUDOQWUREJ3PA7U2S3Z2I75U","additional_properties":{},"content":"Similar ads  also asking for financial contributions and sponsored by multiple Republican members of Congress, candidates and super PACs  have blanketed the platform in recent days. Many represent congressional districts far from the southern border.","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"6XGD5UDBVRHVRPVXFRZTP7KSEE","additional_properties":{},"content":"An ad from Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) asserts that thousands of unvaccinated illegal immigrants enjoy more leniency than American citizens when it comes to health protocols. An ad from Rep. Ted Budd (R-N.C.) warns bluntly, If Joe Biden really wanted to get COVID-19 under control in our country, he would address the crisis at our southern border. Letting unvaccinated ILLEGAL immigrants come into our country is a threat to American citizens. And an ad from Rep. August Pfluger (R-Tex.) alleges, Hundreds of thousands of migrants are pouring into Texas and thousands of them have tested positive for covid-19. All the ads link to fundraising pages.","type":"text","originalIdx":7},{"_id":"PG5PSFN7GVEF7HZ73K54PQ2LJQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Cramer said his ad does not target immigrants and is instead a criticism of Democratic leaders inconsistent liberal policies.","type":"text","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"D3KXOWBKUVGJLKZV5W7ZFFG4GE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Open borders for immigrants with no demands for proof of vaccinations while proposing mandates on American citizens is gross hypocrisy, he wrote in an email response to questions about his ad.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"W5WHNSA5F5CVFIFJXDQBJ42QVA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Lyssa Bell, a spokeswoman for Pfluger, said it was beyond dispute thousands of covid-positive illegal migrants have been released into the interior of Texas. Other lawmakers running such ads did not respond to requests for comment.","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"CAFSZ5DWIFAM3EZOZNHG2ZIWGY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Facebooks allowing the ads appears to be in conflict with the technology giants move last fall to remove ads from President Donald Trumps reelection campaign asserting that accepting more refugees would exacerbate health risks related to the pandemic. At the time, Facebook representatives cited the companys policy against hate speech.","type":"text","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"JPZFOCVBUVEYJHQCU7JR6HEK2Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"We rejected these ads because we dont allow claims that peoples physical safety, health, or survival is threatened by people on the basis of their national origin or immigration status, a Facebook spokesman \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/09/30/biden-misinformation-earpiece-tiktok-facebook/\" target=_blank\u003esaid in September 2020\u003c/a\u003e.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"N7WQTPRMDVBN5MU7YGOXVRY4EE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Now, the claim has returned as Republicans seek to exact a political price from Biden for the \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/biden-border-migrants-expulsion-flights/2021/08/06/1acd2762-f6f5-11eb-83e7-06a8a299c310_story.html\" target=_blank\u003elargest migrant influx\u003c/a\u003e in at least two decades while also blaming him for the surge of coronavirus cases driven by the \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/delta-variant-most-prevalent/2021/08/08/d1017f0e-f558-11eb-9068-bf463c8c74de_story.html\" target=_blank\u003ehighly infectious delta variant\u003c/a\u003e.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"LA7ZZLHKGZHUBK7AN5QE4KKSQQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Devon Kearns, a Facebook spokeswoman, said the ads run by the Republican officials do not violate the companys policies. She drew a distinction with Trumps claims last year by saying the new posts are attacking unvaccinated people or potentially people with covid, which isnt an attack on a protected group.","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"DFBYNJTUARAOPI4RYI2VO7HVW4","additional_properties":{},"content":"The effort to tie the explosion of coronavirus cases to the arrival of migrants has gained currency among Republicans since it was articulated at a news conference and in a fundraising letter last week by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R). But the claim rings false to health experts and fact-checkers, who note that border authorities are denying entry to people more easily than is possible under ordinary immigration law because of an emergency order put in place by Trump in March 2020; that people crossing the border are screened more rigorously for the coronavirus than are members of the general population; and that the positivity rate among migrants in McAllen, Tex., which is at the center of the outcry, is lower than in the surrounding county.","type":"text","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"FES22YI2UFC6XIH6I7JJHKKQ2E","additional_properties":{},"content":"Fact Checker: DeSantiss effort to blame Biden for the covid surge in Florida","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/08/06/desantiss-effort-blame-biden-covid-surge-florida/","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"YOYPYEZQUJDL7OJOUQM5YDYKH4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Who knows if the politicians running these ads believe what theyre saying, said Imran Ahmed, founder and chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, a nonprofit organization that examines online extremism. But they know it pays to say they believe it. Theyve learned from all sorts of bad actors that you can monetize misinformation on social media.","type":"text","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"GKDKX74CQJGL5M2BQT6YDIUV4Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"To fulfill its promise to clean up its platform, Ahmed said, Facebook should become more proactive in vetting paid posts, rather than their default being to take every advertisement that someone wants to buy.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"FZYJEAX3UBGDHDKP2YKHXA7JZU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Its a commercial consideration, he added. There is a tension between their promise not to be a vector for disinformation and their desire to maximize profits.","type":"text","originalIdx":19}],"content_restrictions":{"content_code":"default"},"credits":{"by":[{"_id":"stanleybeckeri","additional_properties":{"original":{"_id":"stanleybeckeri","awards":[],"bio":"Isaac Stanley-Becker is an investigative reporter on the national staff.","bio_page":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/isaac-stanley-becker/","books":[],"byline":"Isaac Stanley-Becker","custom_washpost_desk_name_1":"National","custom_washpost_desk_name_2":"National Investigative","education":[{"name":"Yale University, BA in History"},{"name":"University of Oxford, MA in History"},{"name":"University of Oxford, DPhil in History"}],"email":"isaac.stanley-becker@washpost.com","employeeID":"000268141","expertise":"Investigative reporter on the national staff","firstName":"Isaac","follow-author":true,"image":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/arc-authors/washpost/901e1f16-3cc3-4aff-848f-9fdf0f33214f.png","isWorkdayLoad":true,"jobProfile":"Investigative Reporter","lastName":"Stanley-Becker","last_updated":"2018-10-16T11:04:16.343Z","last_updated_date":"2024-12-06T10:37:58.933Z","location":"Washington, D.C.","longBio":"Isaac Stanley-Becker is an investigative reporter on the national staff of The Washington Post. readabilityObject.title: Republicans raise money on Facebook by tying migrant influx to covid surge
readabilityObject.content:
Facebook has allowed prominent Republican officials and candidates including the chairman of the Senate Republican Conference to use the platforms powerful ad technologies to raise money by associating migrants with the surge of coronavirus infections in the southern United States.

The ads, whose central claim has been rejected by doctors and fact-checkers, illustrate the platforms inconsistent approach to defining coronavirus misinformation, especially when elected officials are involved. Facebooks management of misleading content is under intense scrutiny by the Biden administration as coronavirus case numbers climb again in the United States and health authorities grapple with the role of social media in shaping anti-vaccine attitudes. Biden raised alarm about the issue last month when he said in relation to Facebook, Theyre killing people.

The latest test of the social media giants policies joins the inflamed debate over immigration to the life-or-death matter of the novel coronavirus.

The CDC & Joe Biden are telling Americans to MASK UP but are letting THOUSANDS of COVID-19 positive illegal immigrants into our country! warns an ad from Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Republican Conference and a physician.

The ad, which began running on Aug. 6, has been viewed as many as 15,000 times, according to Facebooks ad archive. It directs users to a petition calling on Biden to visit the southern border and, ultimately, to a fundraising page benefiting the senators campaign committee, Friends of John Barrasso.

Similar ads also asking for financial contributions and sponsored by multiple Republican members of Congress, candidates and super PACs have blanketed the platform in recent days. Many represent congressional districts far from the southern border.

An ad from Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) asserts that thousands of unvaccinated illegal immigrants enjoy more leniency than American citizens when it comes to health protocols. An ad from Rep. Ted Budd (R-N.C.) warns bluntly, If Joe Biden really wanted to get COVID-19 under control in our country, he would address the crisis at our southern border. Letting unvaccinated ILLEGAL immigrants come into our country is a threat to American citizens. And an ad from Rep. August Pfluger (R-Tex.) alleges, Hundreds of thousands of migrants are pouring into Texas and thousands of them have tested positive for covid-19. All the ads link to fundraising pages.

Cramer said his ad does not target immigrants and is instead a criticism of Democratic leaders inconsistent liberal policies.

Open borders for immigrants with no demands for proof of vaccinations while proposing mandates on American citizens is gross hypocrisy, he wrote in an email response to questions about his ad.

Lyssa Bell, a spokeswoman for Pfluger, said it was beyond dispute thousands of covid-positive illegal migrants have been released into the interior of Texas. Other lawmakers running such ads did not respond to requests for comment.

Facebooks allowing the ads appears to be in conflict with the technology giants move last fall to remove ads from President Donald Trumps reelection campaign asserting that accepting more refugees would exacerbate health risks related to the pandemic. At the time, Facebook representatives cited the companys policy against hate speech.

We rejected these ads because we dont allow claims that peoples physical safety, health, or survival is threatened by people on the basis of their national origin or immigration status, a Facebook spokesman said in September 2020.

Now, the claim has returned as Republicans seek to exact a political price from Biden for the largest migrant influx in at least two decades while also blaming him for the surge of coronavirus cases driven by the highly infectious delta variant.

Devon Kearns, a Facebook spokeswoman, said the ads run by the Republican officials do not violate the companys policies. She drew a distinction with Trumps claims last year by saying the new posts are attacking unvaccinated people or potentially people with covid, which isnt an attack on a protected group.

The effort to tie the explosion of coronavirus cases to the arrival of migrants has gained currency among Republicans since it was articulated at a news conference and in a fundraising letter last week by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R). But the claim rings false to health experts and fact-checkers, who note that border authorities are denying entry to people more easily than is possible under ordinary immigration law because of an emergency order put in place by Trump in March 2020; that people crossing the border are screened more rigorously for the coronavirus than are members of the general population; and that the positivity rate among migrants in McAllen, Tex., which is at the center of the outcry, is lower than in the surrounding county.

Who knows if the politicians running these ads believe what theyre saying, said Imran Ahmed, founder and chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, a nonprofit organization that examines online extremism. But they know it pays to say they believe it. Theyve learned from all sorts of bad actors that you can monetize misinformation on social media.

To fulfill its promise to clean up its platform, Ahmed said, Facebook should become more proactive in vetting paid posts, rather than their default being to take every advertisement that someone wants to buy.

Its a commercial consideration, he added. There is a tension between their promise not to be a vector for disinformation and their desire to maximize profits.

But they know it pays to say they believe it. Theyve learned from all sorts of bad actors that you can monetize misinformation on social media.To fulfill its promise to clean up its platform, Ahmed said, Facebook should become more proactive in vetting paid posts, rather than their default being to take every advertisement that someone wants to buy.Its a commercial consideration, he added. There is a tension between their promise not to be a vector for disinformation and their desire to maximize profits.
